title: Authors and Citation
text: Ben Denis Shaffer. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Shaffer B (2025). mrc: mrc. R package version 0.1.0, https://bdshaff.github.io/mrc/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {mrc: mrc},   author = {Ben Denis Shaffer},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.1.0},   url = {https://bdshaff.github.io/mrc/}, }

title: mrc
text: install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("bdshaff/mrc")

what: Define a response form for a nonlinear model — define_response_form
title: Define a response form for a nonlinear model — define_response_form
text: function defines response form nonlinear model based specified type. uses `brms` package create formula response variable.

title: Define a response form for a nonlinear model — define_response_form
Define a response form for a nonlinear model — define_response_form
text: type character string specifying type response form. Valid options "logistic", "log_logistic", "gompertz", "reflected_gompertz", "weibull", "reflected_weibull". x character string representing name predictor variable. y character string representing name response variable.

title: Define a response form for a nonlinear model — define_response_form
text: `brms` formula object representing response form.

title: Define a response form for a nonlinear model — define_response_form
text: function supports following response forms: logistic: \(y = c + ((d - c)/(1 + exp(b*(x - e))))\) log_logistic: \(y = c + ((d - c)/(1 + exp(b*(log(x) - log(e))))\) gompertz: \(y = c + (d - c) * exp(-exp(b * (x - e)))\) reflected_gompertz: \(y = c + (d - c) * (1 - exp(-exp(b * (-x + e))))\) weibull: \(y = c + (d - c) * exp(-exp(b * (log(x) - log(e))))\) reflected_weibull: \(y = c + (d - c) * (1 - exp(-exp(b * (-log(x) + log(e))))\) parameters b, c, d, e model parameters estimated.

title: Define a response form for a nonlinear model — define_response_form

what: Fit a response curve model using brms — fit_response
title: Fit a response curve model using brms — fit_response
text: function fits response curve model using brms package.

title: Fit a response curve model using brms — fit_response
code: fit_response(data, x = NULL, y = NULL, type = "gompertz", ...)

title: Fit a response curve model using brms — fit_response
text: data data frame containing data fitted. x name independent variable (predictor). y name dependent variable (response). type type response curve model fit. Options "gompertz", "logistic", "weibull", "exponential". ... Additional arguments passed brms::brm function.

title: Fit a response curve model using brms — fit_response
text: fitted model object.

title: Fit a response curve model using brms — fit_response
text: function fits response curve model using specified type returns fitted model object.

what: Get the response function from a fitted model — get_response_function
title: Get the response function from a fitted model — get_response_function
text: function extracts response function fitted model object. allows specify location's parameters use (lower, center, upper). #' @param model fitted model object returned `fit_response()`. #' @param location string specifying location's parameters use. Must one "lower", "center", "upper". Default "center". #' @return function takes numeric vector x values returns corresponding y values based specified response model parameters.

title: Get the response function from a fitted model — get_response_function

what: Extract parameters from a fitted model — mrm_extract
title: Extract parameters from a fitted model — mrm_extract
text: function extracts parameters fitted model object.

title: Extract parameters from a fitted model — mrm_extract
Extract parameters from a fitted model — mrm_extract
text: rc_fit fitted model object.

title: Extract parameters from a fitted model — mrm_extract
text: list containing center, lower, upper bounds parameters.

title: Extract parameters from a fitted model — mrm_extract
text: function extracts parameters fitted model object returns list.

what: Infer response from a fitted model — mrm_infer
title: Infer response from a fitted model — mrm_infer
text: function infers response fitted model object.

title: Infer response from a fitted model — mrm_infer
Infer response from a fitted model — mrm_infer
text: mrm fitted model object. xrange numeric vector length 2 specifying range x values prediction. Default NULL, uses range x data. length.integer specifying number points predict. Default 1000.

title: Infer response from a fitted model — mrm_infer
text: data frame containing predicted response values model response.

title: Infer response from a fitted model — mrm_infer
text: function infers response fitted model object returns data frame predicted response values model response.

what: Optimal Mix Function This function computes the optimal mix of channels to maximize the total response given a set of response functions and constraints. — mrm_optimal_mix
title: Optimal Mix Function This function computes the optimal mix of channels to maximize the total response given a set of response functions and constraints. — mrm_optimal_mix
text: Optimal Mix Function function computes optimal mix channels maximize total response given set response functions constraints.

title: Optimal Mix Function This function computes the optimal mix of channels to maximize the total response given a set of response functions and constraints. — mrm_optimal_mix
code: mrm_optimal_mix(   mrm,   total,   x0 = NULL,   lb = NULL,   ub = NULL,   ineq_constr = NULL )

title: Optimal Mix Function This function computes the optimal mix of channels to maximize the total response given a set of response functions and constraints. — mrm_optimal_mix
text: mrm list response functions, function takes numeric vector input returns numeric value. total numeric value representing total budget constraint optimization. x0 optional numeric vector representing initial guess optimization. NULL, default value used. lb optional numeric vector representing lower bounds channel. NULL, default values used. ub optional numeric vector representing upper bounds channel. NULL, default values used. ineq_constr optional function representing additional inequality constraints. NULL, default constraints used.

title: Optimal Mix Function This function computes the optimal mix of channels to maximize the total response given a set of response functions and constraints. — mrm_optimal_mix
text: list containing optimization results, including optimal channel mix maximum response value.

what: Plot the response of a fitted model — mrm_plot_response
title: Plot the response of a fitted model — mrm_plot_response
text: function plots response fitted model.

title: Plot the response of a fitted model — mrm_plot_response
code: mrm_plot_response(mrm, xrange = NULL, length.out = 1000, points = TRUE)

title: Plot the response of a fitted model — mrm_plot_response
text: mrm fitted model object. can brmsfit object list brmsfit objects. xrange vector length 2 specifying range x values plot. NULL, range x values data used. length.integer specifying number points generate x-axis. Default 1000. points logical value indicating whether plot data points. Default TRUE.

title: Plot the response of a fitted model — mrm_plot_response
text: ggplot object.

title: Plot the response of a fitted model — mrm_plot_response
text: function plots response fitted model object. uses ggplot2 create plot includes title subtitle information model.

what: Plot Marginal and Absolute Rates of Return for Multiple Resource Models — mrm_plot_return
title: Plot Marginal and Absolute Rates of Return for Multiple Resource Models — mrm_plot_return
text: function generates plot comparing Marginal Rate Return (MR) Absolute Rate Return (AR) multiple resource models. highlights key points maximum MR intersection point MR equals AR.

title: Plot Marginal and Absolute Rates of Return for Multiple Resource Models — mrm_plot_return
Plot Marginal and Absolute Rates of Return for Multiple Resource Models — mrm_plot_return
text: mrm list fitted model objects (e.g., brmsfit objects). xrange numeric vector length 2 specifying range x values consider. NULL, range determined data. ncol integer specifying number columns facet wrap. Default 2.

title: Plot Marginal and Absolute Rates of Return for Multiple Resource Models — mrm_plot_return
text: ggplot object visualizing MR AR model.

title: Plot Marginal and Absolute Rates of Return for Multiple Resource Models — mrm_plot_return
text: function computes MR AR model list creates faceted plot. highlights maximum MR point red intersection point MR equals AR blue. shaded green area indicates range two points.

what: Get the response function from a fitted model — mrm_response_function
title: Get the response function from a fitted model — mrm_response_function
text: function extracts response function fitted model object. allows specify location's parameters use (lower, center, upper). #' @param model fitted model object returned `fit_response()`. #' @param location string specifying location's parameters use. Must one "lower", "center", "upper". Default "center". #' @return function takes numeric vector x values returns corresponding y values based specified response model parameters.

title: Get the response function from a fitted model — mrm_response_function

what: Get Ranges of Maximum Marginal Returns and Average Returns This function computes the ranges of x values corresponding to the maximum marginal returns (MR) and average returns (AR) for a list of marginal response models (MRMs). — mrm_returns_ranges
title: Get Ranges of Maximum Marginal Returns and Average Returns This function computes the ranges of x values corresponding to the maximum marginal returns (MR) and average returns (AR) for a list of marginal response models (MRMs). — mrm_returns_ranges
text: Get Ranges Maximum Marginal Returns Average Returns function computes ranges x values corresponding maximum marginal returns (MR) average returns (AR) list marginal response models (MRMs).

title: Get Ranges of Maximum Marginal Returns and Average Returns This function computes the ranges of x values corresponding to the maximum marginal returns (MR) and average returns (AR) for a list of marginal response models (MRMs). — mrm_returns_ranges

Get Ranges of Maximum Marginal Returns and Average Returns This function computes the ranges of x values corresponding to the maximum marginal returns (MR) and average returns (AR) for a list of marginal response models (MRMs). — mrm_returns_ranges
text: mrm list fitted model objects (e.g., brmsfit objects). xrange numeric vector length 2 specifying range x values consider. NULL, range determined data.

title: Get Ranges of Maximum Marginal Returns and Average Returns This function computes the ranges of x values corresponding to the maximum marginal returns (MR) and average returns (AR) for a list of marginal response models (MRMs). — mrm_returns_ranges
text: data frame containing channels corresponding x ranges maximum MR AR.

title: Get Ranges of Maximum Marginal Returns and Average Returns This function computes the ranges of x values corresponding to the maximum marginal returns (MR) and average returns (AR) for a list of marginal response models (MRMs). — mrm_returns_ranges
text: function computes MR AR model list identifies x values MR AR maximized. returns data frame channel names respective x ranges.

title: Plot Optimal Mix — plot_optimal_mix
text: function plots response curves along optimal points determined optimization results.

title: Plot Optimal Mix — plot_optimal_mix
Plot Optimal Mix — plot_optimal_mix
text: response_funs named list response functions. res result object optimization containing optimal solution.

title: Plot Optimal Mix — plot_optimal_mix
text: ggplot object showing response curves optimal points.

what: Replace Variables in a Formula — replace_variables_in_formula
title: Replace Variables in a Formula — replace_variables_in_formula
text: function replaces variables given formula new variable names.

title: Replace Variables in a Formula — replace_variables_in_formula
Replace Variables in a Formula — replace_variables_in_formula
text: formula formula object variables need replaced. old_vars character vector variable names replaced. new_vars character vector new variable names replace old ones.

title: Replace Variables in a Formula — replace_variables_in_formula
text: formula object specified variables replaced.

title: Replace Variables in a Formula — replace_variables_in_formula
text: function uses regular expressions match variable names formula.

title: Response Curve Function — response
text: function computes response curve based specified model type. supports Gompertz model Richards model.

title: Response Curve Function — response
Response Curve Function — response
text: x numeric vector representing input values. params list containing parameters model. include: b: slope parameter (numeric). c: lower asymptote (numeric). d: upper asymptote (numeric). e: half-saturation (numeric). type character string specifying model type. can either "gompertz" "richards".

title: Response Curve Function — response
text: numeric vector representing response values computed model.

title: Gompertz Response Model — rm_Gompertz
text: function computes Gompertz response model given vector x values. takes parameters b, c, d, e define Gompertz function.

title: Gompertz Response Model — rm_Gompertz
Gompertz Response Model — rm_Gompertz
text: x numeric vector x values. b numeric value representing steepness curve. c numeric value representing lower asymptote. d numeric value representing upper asymptote. e numeric value representing x-value sigmoid's midpoint.

title: Gompertz Response Model — rm_Gompertz
text: numeric vector length x, representing computed Gompertz response values.

title: Gompertz Response Model — rm_Gompertz
text: Gompertz function defined : $$y = c + (d - c) * exp(-exp( b * (x - e)))$$

title: Gompertz Response Model — rm_Gompertz
code: x_values <- seq(0, 10, by = 0.1) b <- -0.5 c <- 0 d <- 1 e <- 5 result <- rm_Gompertz(x_values, b, c, d, e) plot(x_values, result, type = "l", main = "Gompertz Response Model", xlab = "x", ylab = "y")

title: Reflected Gompertz Response Model — rm_GompertzRef
text: function computes reflected Gompertz response model given vector x values. takes parameters b, c, d, e define reflected Gompertz function.

title: Reflected Gompertz Response Model — rm_GompertzRef
Reflected Gompertz Response Model — rm_GompertzRef
text: x numeric vector x values. b numeric value representing steepness curve. c numeric value representing lower asymptote. d numeric value representing upper asymptote. e numeric value representing x-value sigmoid's midpoint.

title: Reflected Gompertz Response Model — rm_GompertzRef
text: numeric vector length x, representing computed reflected Gompertz response values.

title: Reflected Gompertz Response Model — rm_GompertzRef
text: reflected Gompertz function defined : $$y = c + (d - c) * (1 - exp(-exp( b * (-x + e))))$$

title: Reflected Gompertz Response Model — rm_GompertzRef
code: x_values <- seq(0, 10, by = 0.1) b <- -0.5 c <- 0 d <- 1 e <- 5 result <- rm_GompertzRef(x_values, b, c, d, e) plot(x_values, result, type = "l", main = "Reflected Gompertz Response Model", xlab = "x", ylab = "y")

title: Log-logistic response model — rm_LogLogistic
text: function computes log-logistic response model given vector x values. takes parameters b, c, d, e define log-logistic function.

title: Log-logistic response model — rm_LogLogistic
Log-logistic response model — rm_LogLogistic
text: x numeric vector x values. b numeric value representing steepness curve. c numeric value representing lower asymptote. d numeric value representing upper asymptote. e numeric value representing x-value sigmoid's midpoint.

title: Log-logistic response model — rm_LogLogistic
text: numeric vector length x, representing computed log-logistic response values.

title: Log-logistic response model — rm_LogLogistic
text: log-logistic function defined : $$y = c + \frac{(d - c)}{1 + e^{-b(log(x) - log(e))}}$$

title: Log-logistic response model — rm_LogLogistic
code: x_values <- seq(0, 10, by = 0.1) b <- -2 c <- 0 d <- 1 e <- 5 result <- rm_LogLogistic(x_values, b, c, d, e) plot(x_values, result, type = "l", main = "Log-logistic Response Model", xlab = "x", ylab = "y")

title: Logistic Response Model — rm_Logistic
text: function computes logistic response model given vector x values. takes parameters b, c, d, e define logistic function.

title: Logistic Response Model — rm_Logistic
Logistic Response Model — rm_Logistic
text: x numeric vector x values. b numeric value representing steepness curve. c numeric value representing lower asymptote. d numeric value representing upper asymptote. e numeric value representing x-value sigmoid's midpoint.

title: Logistic Response Model — rm_Logistic
text: numeric vector length x, representing computed logistic response values.

title: Logistic Response Model — rm_Logistic
text: logistic function defined : $$y = c + \frac{(d - c)}{1 + e^{-b(x - e)}}$$

title: Logistic Response Model — rm_Logistic
code: x_values <- seq(0, 10, by = 0.1) b <- -2 c <- 0 d <- 1 e <- 5 result <- rm_Logistic(x_values, b, c, d, e) plot(x_values, result, type = "l", main = "Logistic Response Model", xlab = "x", ylab = "y")

text: x numeric vector x values. b numeric value representing steepness curve. c numeric value representing lower asymptote. d numeric value representing upper asymptote. e numeric value representing x-value sigmoid's midpoint.

title: Weibull Response Model — rm_Weibull
text: numeric vector length x, representing computed Weibull response values.

title: Weibull Response Model — rm_Weibull
text: Weibull function defined : $$y = c + (d - c) * exp(-exp( b * (log(x) - log(e))))$$

title: Weibull Response Model — rm_Weibull
code: x_values <- seq(0, 10, by = 0.1) b <- -1 c <- 0 d <- 1 e <- 5 result <- rm_Weibull(x_values, b, c, d, e) plot(x_values, result, type = "l", main = "Weibull Response Model", xlab = "x", ylab = "y")

title: Reflected Weibull Response Model — rm_WeibullRef

title: Reflected Weibull Response Model — rm_WeibullRef
Reflected Weibull Response Model — rm_WeibullRef
text: x numeric vector x values. b numeric value representing steepness curve. c numeric value representing lower asymptote. d numeric value representing upper asymptote. e numeric value representing x-value sigmoid's midpoint.

title: Reflected Weibull Response Model — rm_WeibullRef
text: numeric vector length x, representing computed reflected Weibull response values.

title: Reflected Weibull Response Model — rm_WeibullRef
text: reflected Weibull function defined : $$y = c + (d - c) * (1 - exp(-exp( b * (-log(x) + log(e)))))$$

title: Reflected Weibull Response Model — rm_WeibullRef
code: x_values <- seq(0, 10, by = 0.1) b <- -5 c <- 0 d <- 1 e <- 5 result <- reflected_weibull_response_model(x_values, b, c, d, e) #> Error in reflected_weibull_response_model(x_values, b, c, d, e): could not find function "reflected_weibull_response_model" plot(x_values, result, type = "l", main = "Reflected Weibull Response Model", xlab = "x", ylab = "y") #> Error: object 'result' not found

title: Dispatch Response Model — rm_dispatch
text: function dispatches appropriate response model based type provided.

title: Dispatch Response Model — rm_dispatch
Dispatch Response Model — rm_dispatch
text: type string indicating type response model dispatch.

title: Dispatch Response Model — rm_dispatch
text: function corresponding specified response model.

title: Dispatch Response Model — rm_dispatch
text: function takes string input `type` returns corresponding response model function. available response models : - "logistic" - "log_logistic" - "gompertz" - "reflected_gompertz" - "weibull" - "reflected_weibull"

what: Set default constraints for optimization — set_dafault_constraints
title: Set default constraints for optimization — set_dafault_constraints
text: function sets default constraints optimization problem, including initial values, lower upper bounds, total constraint function.

title: Set default constraints for optimization — set_dafault_constraints
Set default constraints for optimization — set_dafault_constraints
text: C Number variables total Total sum constraint

title: Set default constraints for optimization — set_dafault_constraints
text: list containing initial values (x0), lower bounds (lb), upper bounds (ub), total constraint function (total_constr_func).

what: Create an objective function for optimization — set_objective_function
title: Create an objective function for optimization — set_objective_function
text: function generates objective function can used optimization routines. objective function computes negative sum outputs list response functions evaluated given set input parameters.

title: Create an objective function for optimization — set_objective_function
Create an objective function for optimization — set_objective_function
text: response_funs list functions. function take single numeric input return numeric output.

title: Create an objective function for optimization — set_objective_function
text: function takes numeric vector input returns negative sum outputs response functions.

text: total numeric value representing desired total sum elements vector.
